content:
ICS 1C HW 2: A Question and Answer Session

About the Author

Name:Steve Hoffman
E-mail: easu568@ea.oac.uci.edu
Major: Social Science

Three neat Web finds:

  1. A great directory exists on various "alternative" subjects such as anarchy, angst, and rainbow gatherings.
  2. Anyone interested in singer/actor/icon Tom Waits can find his very own page full of pictures and information on the Web.
  3. Anyone interested in four-dimensional data assimilation and their impact on future and current problems should go here!

Questions I can now answer
  1. Where can I find a list of Sociology Journals and Magazines on the Web, and especially on Post-Modern culture?
  2. What is SGML and what does it have to do with HTML?
  3. How can I find out about graduate schools in my major, and especially how can I get more information on the University of Washington?
  4. Where can I get more some inside information on Stephen Franklin and get access to his incredible array of resources on the Web, thus aiding my education in this class tenfold?
  5. Where can I find out more about Extropians and better yet, what/who in the world is it?
  1. Where can I find a list of Sociology Journals and Magazines on the Web, and especially on Post-Modern culture? There is an interesting list of worldwide journals of sociology, ranging from numerous schools and locals from all around the world, that is put out on the World Wide Web by the Australian National University(ANU). This list may prove useful to all interested in research in sociology and in the social sciences in general. Of particular interest to those intrigued by postmodern culture is a journal eminating from the University of Virginia. This journal page may also include other links to sites of similar interest. Enjoy.

    Return to list of questions.

  2. What is SGML and what does it have to do with HTML? SGML, or Standard Generalized Markup Language, is a general language used for text information processing. It was adopted for this purpose as an international standard, by the name ISO 8879. Its underlying goal is to facilitate efficient distribution and retrieval of information in a generalized language that will not mandate a specific appearance or interpretation by the client. The SGML standard actually defines the markup language used in creating and disseminating hypertext documents in Hypertext Markup Language, or HTML. HTML defines the structure of a hypertext document such that any client can interpret it according to its program's capabilities. Thus, HTML takes the basic philosophy of generating a flexible markup language and applies it to hypertext and multimedia systems such as the World Wide Web.

    Return to list of questions.

  3. How can I find out about graduate schools in my major, and especially how can I get more information on the University of Washington? There is a fairly comprehensive list of American Universities available on the World Wide Web which is put out by Mike Conlon at the University of Florida. Each link is a name of an American University and takes you to that schools home page, or occassionally to a departmental home page. For an even more comprehensive and extensive list of worldwide University links, there is a fine list of international universities which comes from MIT. Both of these pages will attempt to provide the viewer with a link that will provide access to other departments and resources at the university you choose. For example, the University of Washington's home page is exquisitevely laid out and gives references to its various schools, departments, and sponsored activities.

    Return to list of questions.

  4. Where can I get more some inside information on Stephen Franklin and get access to his vast informational resources on the Web, thus aiding my education in this class tenfold? One can get access to the world renowned and illustrious mentor of the "many" through the department which is simply too small to contain his ever abounding informational capacity. Namely, one can click onto Franklin's home page here which comes from the Office of Academic Computing at the University of California Irvine. If one wants to bypass his home page, which I certainly do not suggest given his grinning mug will greet you there, one can link directly onto his own personal hotlist. Here you will find an extensive and highly useful array of the resources and Web documents that made our hero everything that he is. By accessing this vast repetoire of greatness, we may be able to take over his ICS 1C class by exhibiting our own superior expertise and knowledge of the World Wide Web. Good luck comrades and viva la revolucion.....

    Return to list of questions.

  5. Where can I find out more about Extropians and better yet, what/who in the world is it? The best place to find out more about Extropians is to go directly to the source, or rather to the document on the Web entitled Frequently Asked Questions on Extropians. Extropianism is actually more of a mindset rather than a platform of concrete and hard held ideas. They are most interested in exploration of life and its many facets with a particular emphasis on technology as a means of bridging political and social differences. Extropians, ultimately then, or perpetual and self sustained optimistic explorers who tend not to hold any particular allegiances while advocating infinite creativity and total and boundless expansion. This is not to say there are no Extropian principles to be unearthed in such a morass of "liberation theology". Extropians are intimately tied to humanism in its philisophical base(feeling that the "supernatural" and/or whatever is considered "outside" the range of human knowledge or power is ultimately a pointless and backward unit of study), but attempt to transcend the limits of humanism. Thus, they term themselves as "transhumanists", they believe that we can transcend physical limitations of our biology, culture and environment through the wise and creative use of science and technology.

    Return to list of questions.

Submitted February 07, 1995 for ICS 1C
